title: nymag.com/intelligencer/articl...

last_post.content:
You can get a good sense of her position from @lizweil's *New York Magazine* profile:

https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/ai-artificial-intelligence-chatbots-emily-m-bender.html

Bender has made many important scholarly contributions to her field, but she is also famous for her rules of thumb, which caution her fellow scientists not to get high on their own supply:

* Please do not conflate word form and meaning

* Mind your own credulity

21/

title: newyorker.com/tech/annals-of-t...

last_post.content:
Chiang is still writing some of the best critical work on "AI." His February article in the *New Yorker*, "ChatGPT Is a Blurry JPEG of the Web," was an instant classic:

> [AI] hallucinations are compression artifacts, but—like the incorrect labels generated by the Xerox photocopier—they are plausible enough that identifying them requires comparing them against the originals, which in this case means either the Web or our own knowledge of the world.

https://www.newyorker.com/tech/annals-of-technology/chatgpt-is-a-blurry-jpeg-of-the-web

32/

title: Signal is for everyone, and everyone is different

last_post.content:
To see @signalapp use this language and STILL not get the hypocrisy of removing SMS support is laughable and frustrating.

https://signal.org/blog/signal-is-for-everyone/

Signal is for everyone that is willing to have multiple apps to talk to different people. It was set up to be the happy medium between Android and iMessage that still could fall back in the same way that each of those do. There is a large user base explaining to them over and over again why the functionality is critical but those people, for some reason, aren't included as "everyone".

Those that I got to install Signal did so because it could replace their SMS app..... Those people no longer use it. They are clearly not part of "everyone"

#Signal #SMS #Messaging

At first the police just wanted two hours of footage from this guy's doorbell Ring cam.

"It was just the beginning.

They asked for more footage, now from the entire day’s worth of records. And a week later, Larkin received a notice from Ring itself: The company had received a warrant, signed by a local judge. The notice informed him it was obligated to send footage from more than 20 cameras — whether or not Larkin was willing to share it himself."

Of course, the carnival barkers of the AI pump-and-dump insist that this is all a feature, not a bug. If autocomplete says stupid, wrong things with total confidence, that's because "AI" is becoming *more* human, because humans also say stupid, wrong things with total confidence.

When ventilation rates were at least 10 l/s per student, the infection risk was 80% lower."

title: Commentary: Cory Doctorow: Social Quitting

last_post.content:
Cory Doctorow: Social Quitting
https://locusmag.com/2023/01/commentary-cory-doctorow-social-quitting/
'As I type these words, a mass exodus is underway from Twitter and Facebook. After decades of eye-popping growth, these social media sites are contracting at an alarming rate.

In some ways, this shouldn’t surprise us. All the social networks that preceded the current generation experienced this pattern: SixDegrees, Friendster, MySpace, and Bebo all exploded onto the scene. One day, they were sparsely populated fringe services, the next day, every­one you knew was using them and you had to sign up to stay in touch. Then, just as quickly, they imploded, turning into ghost towns, then punchlines, then forgotten ruins.

This didn’t happen to Facebook and Twitter. Both attained a scale and durability that exceeded the networks that preceded them. For many people, it seemed like the operators of these services had cracked the nut of making eternal social media. Maybe it was their access to the capital markets, which let them hire better engineering teams? Maybe it was the singular genius of their founders and leaders? Maybe it was luck?

Today, it’s getting harder to believe that these networks will last forever. In the blink of an eye, they’ve gone from unassailable eternal mountains to shifting sands that might blow away at any time. Users are scrambling to download their data and tell their friends where they can be found if (when?) the service disappears.' @doctorow

title: Russia fines Wikipedia for publishing facts instead of Kremlin war propaganda

last_post.content:
For a third time, a Russian court has fined the Wikimedia Foundation for failing to delete so-called "misinformation" about Russia's military from Wikipedia.

Wikimedia says, "These are part of several takedown orders and fines from Russian authorities we have continued to receive for failing to comply with similar requests. We have not taken down any content and already have two active appeals for fines on similar topics."

title: There’s a Growing Crisis in Our Social Lives. Is the Cure This Simple?

last_post.content:
"[W]e’re all losing the ability to engage in what I view as the pinnacle of human interaction: sitting around with friends and talking shit. [...] In an age of shortened attention spans, to go through hours of anything together with someone else is so unusual that it can throw our brains into a kind of joyful crisis state."

Another reason why we need in-person conferences: the kind of shared mental environment in which new patterns of knowing can emerge... I have been delighted to respond to e-mail messages from old friends who heard my zoomed paper at the #NarrativeConference last week, but at the same time I lack the thought-buzz I would have gained from all the new people I now did not get to hang out with.

#intersubjectivity #HangingOut #cognition

https://slate.com/culture/2023/02/hanging-out-sheila-liming-book-friendship-crisis.html

title: How Bill Gates’ Minesweeper addiction helped lead to the Xbox

last_post.content:
The story of Minesweeper's early popularity at Microsoft illuminates the addicting time-sink the game would later become, even becoming so distracting for Bill Gates that employees had to step in to get him to focus.
https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2023/02/how-bill-gates-minesweeper-addiction-helped-lead-to-the-xbox/?utm_brand=ars

title: masto-list-importer

last_post.content: Ok, so moving to another Mastodon server *is* easy, but list migration still isn't. If you follow more than a hundred or so accounts, sorting your follows into separate feeds via Lists is super helpful. You can export your lists, but there's no import process and rebuilding them manually is painful. As usual though, there's a community tool for every Mastodon problem. My lists are back in order thanks to @Eliot_L's masto-list-importer: https://www.eliotlash.com/masto-list-importer/

title: GitHub - BlinkDL/RWKV-LM: RWKV is a RNN with transformer-level LLM performance. It can be directly trained like a GPT (parallelizable). So it's combining the best of RNN and transformer - great performance, fast inference, saves VRAM, fast training, "infinite" ctx_len, and free sentence embedding.

last_post.content:
[D] Why isn't everyone using RWKV if it's so much better than transformers?

https://github.com/BlinkDL/RWKV-LM

Discussions: https://discu.eu/q/https://github.com/BlinkDL/RWKV-LM

#compsci #machinelearning

title: Elon Musk Wants to Relive His Start-Up Days. He’s Repeating the Same Mistakes.

last_post.content:
Not only does Elon Musk not have a clue what he’s talking about, but this is *exactly* what he tried to do at PayPal, claiming it needed a full “V2” rewrite of the code when it didn’t.

Instead, it shifted resources away from key areas, caused PayPal to lose much more money to fraud, and eventually got him ousted as CEO.

Last month, I wrote about Elon Musk’s time at PayPal and how he’s repeating his mistakes from that period: https://www.disconnect.blog/p/elon-musk-wants-to-relive-his-start

#tech #elonmusk #twitter #paypal

title: Opinion | How ChatGPT Hijacks Democracy

last_post.content:
In 2017, bots submitted over a million comments opposing net neutrality to the FCC. In my view, this man-in-the-middle attack on democracy has been one of the most under-discussed of the past decade.

Somehow last January I missed this piece from Nathan Sanders and Bruce Schneier on how LLMs will turbocharge the threat of similar exploits.

Below, paywall-free link.
https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/15/opinion/ai-chatgpt-lobbying-democracy.html?unlocked_article_code=61TJbKENncOjj4w0qdmX6R_JU9qkQgfcQhqrcslgJBgUWRr34GgvJnhcTuBrCqNMFgMB3tKIJy1TSWLn2gCMbe56i9r9ij9dlwWbiKaF6ht0nlKU2UYd2gNOB1lhcM0yd4nQ8bwRWYVRIPxvaaGqYI9c-KfCyZgPP2u3m3GbMUem-XTDYNKROjD5Aaub68qbX5d9cJRGYeIYpDOXIE6U01rRZXJUCZTOE8_GbD-DelTGJOiJ11HfeSTaHQOylJB2NbdMYr8zNM6U4ToAIN8mralQzFyaB97_UvjykNsVXKxRtT7FsQ1Ele8KKb5UnI6Mkf39axMJaw8n4v4HpEXnRB5i_4fu5oE&smid=url-share

title: bomrang/get_satellite_imagery.R at main · ropensci-archive/bomrang

last_post.content:
I'm working on a spiritual successor to the now-retired {bomrang} package. Some of the functionality is being ported over and so I have a question.

What would you as users like `get_satellite_imagery()` to return in the R session? A {stars} object, a {terra} spatRaster (as in {bomrang}) or something else? The original starts out as a geostationary satellite geoTiff file.

Here's the original function for reference: https://github.com/ropensci-archive/bomrang/blob/main/R/get_satellite_imagery.R #RStats #Spatial #RemoteSensing #SatelliteImagery

title: https://glitch.com

last_post.content:
Tik Tok is next to tell you what kind of links you can put on your online profile.

"TikTok has begun blocking links to app stores in creators’ bios, [....] The block [...] also extends to third-party link-in-bio solutions like Linktree."

And this is why you need to own your web presence, even if it's a basic, single page hosted on https://neocities.org or https://glitch.com.

https://techcrunch.com/2023/03/08/tiktok-begins-blocking-links-to-app-store-pages-from-creators-bios via @Sarahp

#IndieWeb #OpenWeb #news #TikTok

Gebru is always a must watch, and this fiery discussion is no exception - eviscerating the overhyped LLM/generative AI bubble by clearly and concisely enumerating the issues with these approaches from a variety of perspectives. title: The Federal Government Is Investigating an Illinois School Where Students With Disabilities Were Frequently Arrested

last_post.content:
Over the course of just one recent academic year, this Illinois school for disabled kids had police arrest HALF the entire student body.

Now the feds have opened a civil rights investigation, following reporting by @ProPublica and Chicago Tribune

#Illinois #Schools #Students #Arrest #Police #CivilRights #Education #Disabled #Disability

https://www.propublica.org/article/federal-investigation-illinois-garrison-school-arrests?utm_medium=social&utm_source=mastodon&utm_campaign=mastodon-post

title: Understanding Social Media Recommendation Algorithms | Knight First Amendment Institute

last_post.content:
For years I’ve felt there needs to be an accessible primer on social media recommendation algorithms. So I used my sabbatical to write one! We can level up normative/policy debates about social media if the tech is better understood.

In the essay I also discuss the flaws of engagement optimization and the optimization mindset in general. I have strong opinions on this and I don’t mince words. I’ve clearly separated the normative analysis from the expository parts.
https://knightcolumbia.org/content/understanding-social-media-recommendation-algorithms

title: Tools for a Better Tomorrow - LIDAR Magazine

last_post.content:
I only met Martin once many years ago at the Bremen FOSS4G Europe conference in 2014. Even not being a LIDAR user, I followed him afterward, also his weird behaviors on mailing lists and social media, totally ignorant of the illness that he was suffering.

Nevertheless, this is a good read about our industry and mental health; and with all the sadness and struggle, the outcome is still positive thanks to the effort of his legacy holders for years to come.

https://lidarmag.com/2023/02/14/tools-for-a-better-tomorrow/?fbclid=IwAR1BzDkOXos866mTNJbhTSKY99rhfaG1T9sNnAHQIZvGzojmltJA47IXBsI

title: Why Chatbots are bound to spout bullshit

last_post.content:
Why Chatbots are bound to spout bullshit

Much has changed since 1986, when the Princeton philosopher Harry Frankfurt published an essay in an obscure journal, Raritan, titled “On Bullshit”. Yet the essay, later republished as a slim bestseller, remains unnervingly relevant. Frankfurt’s brilliant insight was that bullshit lies outside the realm of truth and lies. A liar cares about the tru

https://timharford.com/2023/03/why-chatbots-are-bound-to-spout-bullshit/

#UndercoverEconomist

title: We read the paper that forced Timnit Gebru out of Google. Here’s what it says.

last_post.content:
This was a dig at the #StochasticParrots paper, a comprehensive, measured roundup of criticisms of AI that led Google to fire @timnitGebru, a respected AI researcher, for having the audacity to point out the Emperor's New Clothes:

https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/12/04/1013294/google-ai-ethics-research-paper-forced-out-timnit-gebru/

Gebru's co-author on the Parrots paper was @emilymbender, a computational linguistics specialist at UW, who is one of the best-informed and most damning critics of AI hype.

20/
